content: The "Biennial Appropriations Act" may be cited as the short title. Section 300 of the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 is amended to revise the timetable for the congressional budget process. The timetable for the congressional budget process includes the President submitting the budget by the first Monday in February, the Congressional Budget Office submitting a report by February 15, Committees submitting views and estimates within 6 weeks, Budget Committees reporting a concurrent resolution by April 1, Congress completing action on the resolution by April 15, and appropriation bills being considered by May 15. The House Appropriations Committee reports the last appropriation bill by June 10, Congress completes action on reconciliation legislation by June 15, and the House completes action on biennial appropriation bills and the defense appropriation bill by June 30. On August 1, Congress completes action on biennial appropriation bills and the defense appropriation bill. On October 1, the fiscal year begins. In the case of the first session of Congress following a leap year, with a new President, specific dates will override the usual schedule. The schedule for budget-related actions includes deadlines for the President's budget submission, reports from the Congressional Budget Office, committee submissions, and Congress's completion of the budget resolution. On July 20, the House completes action on biennial appropriation bills and the defense appropriation bill. By August 1, Congress completes action on biennial appropriation bills, the defense appropriation bill, and reconciliation legislation. The fiscal year begins on October 1. In odd-numbered years, Congress enacts an annual defense appropriation bill and biennial appropriation bills for Financial Services, Transportation, Housing and Urban Development, Interior, Environment, and Labor, Health and Human Services, Education. In even-numbered years, Congress considers and enacts an annual defense appropriation bill and biennial appropriation bills for Agriculture, Commerce, Justice, Science, Energy and Water, Homeland Security, and Legislative Branch. In even-numbered years, Congress considers and enacts annual defense appropriation bill and biennial appropriation bills for various departments, including Agriculture, Commerce, Justice, Science, Energy and Water, Homeland Security, Legislative Branch, and State-Foreign Operations. SEC. 3. AMENDMENTS TO THE CONGRESSIONAL BUDGET AND IMPOUNDMENT CONTROL ACT OF 1974. The Congressional Budget Act of 1974 is amended to define "biennium" as a 2-year period starting on October 1. Committee allocations are also adjusted to include appropriations for each fiscal year in the biennium and the first fiscal year for defense. The Congressional Budget Act of 1974 is amended to include appropriations for each fiscal year in the biennium and the first fiscal year for defense. The Congressional Budget Act of 1974 is amended to include appropriations for each fiscal year in the biennium and the first fiscal year for defense. The amendment involves changing the wording related to the total of fiscal years covered by the resolution. SEC. 4. AMENDMENTS TO TITLE 31, UNITED STATES CODE. Amendment to Title 31, United States Code includes defining 'biennium' and adjusting budget contents and submission to Congress for fiscal years. Amendment to Title 31, United States Code involves adjusting budget contents and submission to Congress for fiscal years, including defining 'biennium' and modifying various sections related to fiscal years. Amendment to Title 31, United States Code involves modifying sections related to fiscal years, including allowances, uncontrolled expenditures, and tax expenditures for each fiscal year in the biennium. Amendment to Title 31, United States Code includes changes to tax expenditures for each fiscal year in the biennium. Amendment to Title 31, United States Code changes tax expenditures to bienniums instead of fiscal years. Amendment to Title 31, United States Code changes tax expenditures to bienniums instead of fiscal years for the 2 most recently completed fiscal years. Amendment to Title 31, United States Code changes tax expenditures to bienniums instead of fiscal years for each even-numbered year. Recommendations are made to meet estimated deficiencies by adjusting the fiscal year in the biennium for each fiscal year. Capital Investment Analysis is also addressed in the amendment. Amendment to Title 31, United States Code changes tax expenditures to bienniums instead of fiscal years for each even-numbered year. Capital Investment Analysis is also addressed in the amendment by adjusting the biennium to which the budget relates. SEC. 5. Two-year appropriations; title and style of appropriations acts. Section 105 of title 1, United States Code is amended to specify the title and style of appropriations Acts for nondefense and defense purposes. Nondefense Acts will have a specific format, while defense Acts will have a different format. The appropriations for defense are specified in an Act for the fiscal year, with amounts specified for each fiscal year. Definitions for terms like "biennium" are provided, and Acts described in the section are considered as provided in the Congressional Budget and Impoundment Control Act of 1974. The table of sections for chapter 2 of title 1, United States Code, is amended by striking the item relating to section 105 and inserting the following: considered as provided in section 300(b) of the Congressional Budget Act of 1974. SEC. 6. MULTIYEAR AUTHORIZATIONS. Title III of the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 is amended to include authorizations of appropriations. Sec. 316 prohibits considering bills authorizing appropriations for less than 2 fiscal years unless no further appropriations are needed. It also delays authorization or revenue bills until after the budget resolution and all appropriations bills are completed. The Congressional Budget and Impoundment Control Act of 1974 outlines restrictions on the consideration of appropriations bills and reconciliation bills in the Senate. Certain exceptions apply, such as defense measures, privileged measures, matters in Executive Session, and specific types of bills. The Act also amends the table of contents to include these provisions. SEC. 7. CONGRESSIONAL OVERSIGHT. In each year without required funding under the Congressional Budget Act, House and Senate committees must hold joint oversight hearings with the Appropriations Committee subcommittees to review agency missions, biennial budgeting impact on efficiency, and cost savings. The curr_chunk discusses the benefits of biennial budgeting, including cost savings, new programs created, and programs terminated in the off year of the agency budget. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will assess the impact and feasibility of transitioning to a 2-year fiscal period with a biennial budget process. A report on the findings will be submitted to the Senate and House Committees on the Budget within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The Act and its amendments will take effect on January 1, 2016, applying to budget resolutions and appropriations for the biennium starting in fiscal year 2017.
